segments.text: I went to JPL to interview for a job.
And as the supervisor of the astronomy group, I did the interviewing.
So that was in, I guess, sometime in 1961.
And what did you think of when you first met him?
He does not act like the public's typical image of what an astronomer should act like.
No.
but he had a lot of enthusiasm and a lot of bounce to him.
He was obviously knowledgeable, and he was interested in working in a field where not too many people were interested in working, and that seemed more than adequate to me to offer the man a job.
Later, of course, we became very close personal friends, and it's a little hard since I've been in touch with him
all of the time for the past 30 years to really remember back to what I thought of him 30 years ago.
I can't help, I can't separate that from the contemporary Spinrad, but...
He got pretty unhappy here at JPL.
He got unhappy here because he couldn't get telescope time.
And he, when he came here, assumed that he would be treated like any other young astronomer.
And he found out to the contrary.
He found out that people were simply not giving time on large telescopes to do planetary projects.
They were looked down upon.
And he tried to mine the old plate vaults at Mount Wilson.
They were willing to have him do that.
But as far as getting new time...
McDonald or Mount Wilson, no luck.
So he started looking around, and when he got a job offer from his old alma mater, he left and went to Berkeley.
Okay, let's discuss the world's greatest planetary astrophysicist, Gerard Peter Kuiper.
Why don't you first cross paths with him?
Well, Kuiper was around the lab all of the time in the early days of the space program.
And Kuiper, of course, tended to look upon anyone at JPL as being a good guy.
Because to him, the people at JPL were building the kinds of spacecraft that he was interested in.
They were promoting the kind of work that he wanted to do.
And they were potential sources of funds.
And so anybody who worked at JPL was his friend.
saw anyone he recognized from JPL at a meeting and he tended to back you into the corner and began to harangue you with his latest theories and ideas and he was a great guy.
On the other hand, if you were on an opposing team, he could be a pretty wicked player.
I don't remember when I first met him.
I know he came to the lab regularly.
We had meetings with him throughout the period from, say, 59 on.
But I couldn't give you an exact date.
How about Girard de Vaucouleur?
Well, I worked with de Vaucouleur on committees that were set up by NASA to look into the need for planetary telescopes.
I attended these meetings, usually with Al Hibbs, sometimes not.
But people involved included Al Wilson, , Stan Greenfield, who I guess was with RAND Corporation at the time.
We sometimes met with people like, I don't know, what was his name, Edson, I guess it was, who was
at the Pentagon at the time as a civilian scientist at the Pentagon.
Anyway, I met de Vaucouleur working on these various teams together where we were trying to get support for a NASA building, one or more large planetary telescopes.
And he was, of course, very enthused about his Mars work at the time, met with him often, and enjoyed his company very much.
Tell me billions and billions of things about Carl Sagan.
Well, Carl, of course, was a graduate student of Kuiper's when Kuiper first went to Arizona.
In fact, I guess he was a graduate student before Kuiper went to Arizona and followed him there from Chicago.
I guess Carl's PhD is actually still a Chicago PhD since he began it there.
But I called Kuiper one day and said,
Gee, we've been interested in ideas about solar system cosmology and the origin of the solar system and a lot of disagreement on this, but you've done a lot of work in the field.
Could you sort of write us a position paper that tells us what at least your current ideas are on where things stand with our knowledge of how the solar system originally, how it originated?
And he said, gee, I wish I could, but I'm awfully busy.
However, I've got this very, very bright young graduate student named Carl Sagan, and I'm sure he'd do a bang-up job for you.
And he really needs the money.
He's very poor, and he'd do a great job, and it'd work out well all around.
And so I said, well, fine, sure, we'll let Carl work on this.
And so we met Carl.
He was, of course, working on his thesis on the greenhouse model of the Venus atmosphere.
And after he had pretty well along, why, he came up to the lab and gave us a seminar on the greenhouse model of the Venus atmosphere.
And we all met him and known him ever since.
Was he self-assured even then?
He was pretty self-confident even in those days, yes, very much so for a graduate student.
Yeah, he was always a very confident person, but not overbearing or anything.
He was just quite sure of what he did.
Where did you first meet Harlan Smith, and what did you think of him when you saw him?
Harlan Smith, to me at the time, seemed one of the senior astronomers of the world.
I don't remember where I first met Harlan.

I remember many incidents where I was with him, like just the two of us had dinner together at Snowmass, Colorado, when we were both there for a meeting of the National Academy Solar System Exploration Committee.
And I talked to him many times at meetings
American Astronomical Society or of the Planetary Sciences Division.
He, of course, hosted a couple of meetings of the Planetary Sciences Division at Austin.
I ran into him in many places, but I really don't remember where I first met Harlan or when.
But it was always a great pleasure to talk to him.
I always felt that although he was a very senior man in the field, that he always treated everyone as if they were equal and seemed to respect other people's opinions.

He was always an exciting person to talk to and that he was always full of both ideas about astronomy and knowledge of the current political situation and trying to get new telescopes or new probes or whatever underway.
And I was always very happy when I could
could sit down and talk to him.
The last time I saw him was at the AAS meeting in Pasadena about five years ago.
And there he grabbed me and said he had this very bright young woman who was about to get her PhD at Texas and wondered if there might be any place for her at JPL.
It was Jackie Green.
And I met Jackie, talked to her, and was very much impressed by her.
It turns out she went to Hawaii for a couple of years, but she is, in fact, now at JPL.
But he was looking after his graduate students, as he always did, and making a good case for them.
Actually, I don't think she was his student.
I think she was Roman Smolakowski's student.
But she was there in the department, and he was looking out for them.
Tell me something about Roger Moore.
Didn't have a close relationship with Roger.
Knew Roger when he was at headquarters.
Served on a committee or two with him.
Was never close to Roger.
Never had any private dinners with him or anything like that.
Couldn't really tell you much about Roger.
Maybe you can tell me something about Nancy Roman.
Oh, I could tell you some things about Nancy.
Nancy and I served together on the Astronomy Subcommittee of NASA from 1960 to 62.
Nancy, of course, chaired that committee.
So in a sense, I worked for her.
I was JPL's delegate for the first two years to that august group.
Bill Brunk, for a part of that time, was the representative from Lewis Research Center, where he worked at the time, then left when he went back to finish his PhD.
We had a lot of outstanding consultants on it.
And that's another story in and of itself.
But I worked with Nancy fairly closely for two years.
And to be blunt about it, I was not always happy with Nancy.
I think the thing that really frosted me was her very, very down-the-nose attitude toward solar system astronomy generally.
She felt that it was very distinctly inferior to stellar and galactic work.
And I remember when we had a meeting of the committee at the lab one time, she sort of took me aside and said,
rather confidentially, that she'd been talking to Ira Bowen and that he had agreed that there were still some things that could be done from the ground in planetary astronomy.

And she gave me this information as if it were a great discovery and something that, boy, wasn't this interesting, that the great man, the director of Mount Wilson and Palomar Observatory, actually said there were still some things that could be done from the ground in solar system astronomy.
And she was very surprised by this.
Well, I was promoting within the astronomy committee the need for NASA to build their own planetary telescope because of the difficulty of getting time.
And I remember a meeting we had at Ames.
I guess it was the last meeting that I represented the lab.
I'd served my two years.
People present included, for example, Jesse Greenstein as a consultant,
We had on that committee people like Freeman Dyson, for example, was a consultant to the committee.
There were a lot of big names there.
Anyway, I made my pitch.
It probably took 10 minutes saying why I felt it was important that NASA build their own planetary telescope.
She turned to Gary Mulders, who was representing the National Science Foundation.
Well, what do you think about this?
And Mulders said that, well, he agreed totally with what I had said, that...
The NSF could not support building additional telescopes.

They were hard-pressed to keep up with their requirements as they were, and that he thought NASA indeed should go ahead and build their own planetary telescope, that they should support planetary astronomy.
So she asked Jesse Greenstein, and Greenstein said, well, yeah, I quite agree.
There are a number of things, useful things that can be done from the ground yet.
NASA ought to do them.
They're not going to get enough time to do them on existing telescopes.

and yeah they should do it well i went away feeling really good i mean the whole committee had backed me up nasa ought to build a telescope well that was my last meeting but somebody else then later showed me the minutes of that meeting and nowhere in those minutes of that meeting do you ever find any part of this discussion that strongly supports nasa building a planetary telescope and that really frosted me that had just been written out of the minutes
Tell me something about Bill Brunk, who actually ran the ground-based planetary astronomy for longer than everybody else put together, I guess.
Yeah, I think that's true.

Bill and I, of course, met each other when we were representatives from JPL and from Lewis on this initial Nancy Roman Planetary Astronomy, or not Planetary Astronomy, but this was the Astronomy Subcommittee, which included, at that time, solar system astronomy, solar astronomy, stellar and galactic astronomy.
It covered all of astronomy.
So that...
We got to be friends and work together on that committee.
And then he left to go back and finish his PhD, and then came back to headquarters as an employee.
And Bill and I worked together closely over the years.
He was my program manager when I was leader of the International Halley Watch.
And we always got along well together.
He supported me pretty well.
I have no real complaints about that.

I often felt, however, that as people seem to do when they spend a long period of time in Washington, D.C., I think they tend to lose touch with the realities in the field, as it were, and in the field of astronomy, and they tend to become more concerned about
how do I fit what I want to do within my budget and how do I satisfy the boss, then am I suggesting what's best for astronomy?
And so I often disagreed with him on whether he was really doing what was best for the field.
I felt he was out of touch at times, but he tended to annoy me a little sometimes.
But we always got along well.
Do you think planetary astronomers mind out?
No.
I think there are, as long as the planets have atmospheres, those atmospheres are going to change.
We don't even understand our own, let alone the atmospheres of the other planets.
I think continuing study of the major planets is certainly in order.
Until we have some kind of permanent presence in orbit around Mars or something, there's some...

work perhaps yet to be done on Mars but I think particularly in the small bodies of the solar system there are so many of them that even if we eventually get missions to a few of them one or a comet or two a few asteroids there are so many of them out there that the only way that it's ever all going to be tied together is from a ground-based study of these objects and uh
I think even solar system planetary astronomy has got a lot of future ahead of it because of the impossibility of doing it all from space.
What's the position of planetary astronomy at JPL right now?
I think there is a little sense of dread, a sense of
Maybe we've seen the best days of it.
I think there's a morale problem at JPL today, to be perfectly frank.
The lab has generally been an ebullient place to work, a place where everybody sort of felt that the sky was the limit, upward and onward.
We're doing great things.
And next year, we're going to do even greater ones.
I think that was true for many years.
And I think there has now come a realization that,
This isn't going to continue to happen quite that way.
We're being forced, probably correctly, to do business in different ways in the sense that the multi-billion dollar missions are just not going to be flown.
We've got to fly smaller missions.
There is a change of direction.
This always means some heartbreak for people who've been involved in the old way of doing business for a time.
And I think among the planetary people in general,
the lack of support, we've seen the loss of a number of very good people simply because they can no longer get their ground-based work funded.
And I think there's a certain loss of morale and a fear of the future, perhaps, rather than an eagerness for the future.
It's not a palpable thing exactly, but everybody's concerned.
Let's put it that way.
Well, that also answers what was going to be my next question, what do you think of the future?

But again, this has got to be a guess, but you'll recall in the past there were always been rumors they were going to close JPL and make it the foothill campus of Pasadena City College or something like that.
And of course, NASA does have big budgets.
In the long-term future, do you see JPL around in 20 years, and do you see any planetary astronomy being done at JPL if it's still here?
I think JPL will still be here in 20 years, yeah.
I think it'll be a rather different place than it is today.
I think it won't have the outriggers that it does today, that is the least space around town.
I think it'll probably all be here on one campus, so to speak, except for the computing facility at Woodbury.
I think that the missions that we fly will be smaller, perhaps a bit more often than the big missions, but much smaller missions.
I think that there will perhaps be a tauter, tighter management in the sense that I think that you'll find more a skunkworks approach to things.
You won't throw people at a project, so to speak, that people will be just doing things a little differently than they've traditionally been done at the lab.
And I think the same thing is true of...
ground-based astronomy.

I think there will always remain people here in the field, but I think that the number may be somewhat smaller, and I think that most people, instead of being able to spend 100 percent time on research, there's almost nobody doing that now even, although there were years ago.
I think you'll find everybody will have maybe half time working on one of these projects, half time on their research,

I think JPL will continue to exist, will continue to be a very reputable and enjoyable even place to work, but I think that the feeling of youthful enthusiasm, well, at least among some of us older ones, it isn't there anymore.
We're not so young anymore is perhaps the answer to that.
I shouldn't really answer for what some of the new young people coming in may think about it.
Since planetary astronomy got back into high gear about 30 years or so ago, what do you think the taxpayers have gotten out of it?
Well, I think there have been a number of useful things that have come out of the program, and you can go at this at many, many different levels.
I think they've gotten a sense of almost a competition with the Soviets, and I think that the American public generally enjoys a good contest.
I think they've got the feeling that we won some of it.
I think they've been excited and had their minds opened a little bit by some of the discoveries.
I think that's good.
Clearly, the advances in miniaturization and computing and so on that were necessary for a lot of our space activities have been carried on into
the regular commercial life.
One might argue that perhaps the Japanese have made better use of these discoveries than we have in the commercial sector, but certainly people have very cheap, extremely potent desk computers today.
I don't know how much of this would have happened without the space program.
Maybe it would have happened anyway, but certainly I would feel it wouldn't have happened as soon.
And I think this is true in the medical field.

I think there have been a lot of great advances, miniaturization and so on, application of laser technology and so on, some of which was developed within the space program that's being applied here on Earth.
You can really, I think just trying to open young people's eyes to the

universe to the impressiveness the fascination of it to give them the impression that there's something more important out there than than accounting or or belonging to a gang is important it gives the people the young people a sense of place in the universe and that maybe there's something that they can go out and do that will add to the
good of the world as opposed to just simply being consumers.
I don't know.
What do you think modern planetary astronomy has done for astronomy as a whole?
Hmm.
I hadn't thought about that one.
You think it's shaken them up a little bit?
Oh, it probably has.
I'm sure there's been some instrumentation that's been developed by planetary people for use on space probes that's been applied to telescopes.

I think a lot of the development, though, has been military and then has dribbled down into both planetary and classical galactic and stellar astronomy rather than any direct exchange just between the branches of astronomy.
Well, in addition to that, I'm thinking of theories of star formation, which now, I guess, have to include planets.
Well, that's certainly true.
I mean, the discovery of the dust and what have you around...
several stars on Fomalhaut, I guess.
Beta Pictoris was the first one, yeah.
And I guess there's some hints of material around Vega.
That certainly has, they've interacted, let's put it that way.
Well, as I said,

Solar system astronomers, planetary astronomers, and stellar astronomers do talk to each other today and I think have some appreciation of the work that each other is doing, and I think that both fields are more fruitful for it.
This is getting awfully general now, but what do you think planetary astronomy has done for science as a whole?
It's obviously affecting something like biology, and I don't know about geology and meteorology.
I don't know about chemistry so much.
Well, what do you think?
Well, sure.
Again, one of the things that the space program in general has done is made us aware of the

fragileness of our own environment and clearly if you're going to understand the Earth's atmosphere those same theories ought to apply to other planets and so we've got a number of test subjects now where we can try to apply general meteorological theories which I'm sure that studies of atmosphere of Venus and the major planets have had impact on our studies of our own atmosphere and
Clearly, the studies toward the planet Earth, as NASA now puts it, are of great and even grave interest to the future of the human race.
Considerations of the greenhouse effect of the ozone holes have a lot to say about whether we'll even survive.
Of course, ultimately, there is the
job of mapping out the small near-Earth asteroids to the extent that if one really does threaten the Earth, maybe we can do something about it in the future.

It isn't to say we ought to mount any program now to do it, but what we ought to be doing is trying to find all of these bodies so we know if any of them are going to become a threat and they have an impact on everything, every person's life in that sense.
But as far as direct impacts on science,
All science is a unity, really, and I've just not thought about the direct interchanges, say, between astronomy and chemistry.
It's had enormous impacts on physics, clearly.
I mean, the interactions between astronomy and physics, they're one.
Astronomy is just physics applied to the study of extraterrestrial subjects.

You often hear the statements made, such as the space program has given us a view of the Earth as seen from outside as a planet, and studies, ground-based and probes of other planets have shown, yeah, it is just another planet, but unique and so on.
But do you think the public has really changed its attitude towards, or the way it thinks about Earth, or just changed its attitude, period?
Well...
I think there has been a change.

I think the average man in the street doesn't stop to think each day that he should be concerned about whether the earth is heating up or whether the ozone hole is going to cause him to have skin cancer or not.
But certainly among those who read the daily newspapers or weekly news magazines or even those who listen to the TV news cannot help but be
much more aware of their world and of the fragile nature of that world as a result of the space program, and in particular of various kinds of solar system studies.
They have to be more aware of it and more concerned about it.
I mean, in the past, man is largely worried about warfare, man against man, but now I think he is finally becoming very aware, or should be, that
that he may be doing himself in with some of his activities, both as to use of resources and his disposal of materials.
When you meet people, strangers, say, on an airplane, they're sitting next to you, what's their reaction when they find out what you do for a living?
Most of them, oh, gee, that's interesting.
And then they usually think a minute, and gee,
Have you heard about and something that they've read somewhere or heard somewhere and were kind of curious about, and can you tell me anything about thus and so?
That's often happened.
They're usually fascinated.
So at least in your experience, it's a positive image.
I would say so, yeah.
Originally, and for the first few decades, JPL was just strictly...
let's face it, working for the Army as a contractor developing weapons.
When you first came here, was that still a situation?
Yes.
Okay.
When did JPL get handed over to the SA?
Well, we did, of course, work with the Army in putting up the initial explorers, and then when
We were talking with the Army and with the defense people about doing additional space-type missions that were more research than anything else before NASA came into existence.
But NASA then, of course, was founded and immediately
They were told that they could take over existing laboratories if the laboratories were willing to be taken over to work with them on the space program that had been proposed.
And so they said, well, since we had worked on the Explorers, we're the obvious place to turn to.
They'd like to have JPL.
And people at JPL were very enthused about this.
Most of the people here felt they'd much rather work on studies of the solar system than they would work on...
on military field artillery, long-range field rockets, and that kind of thing, especially since that knowledge was applicable to the new space program as well.
So that by the end of 58, everybody here was very enthused about being a part of NASA.
I think it was in 58 that NASA took us over then with great enthusiasm on everybody's part here.
Not that we disliked the Army people we worked for.
I mean, in some ways, working for the Army was a rather pleasant experience in that we had a real skunk-works approach to things in those days.
The Army would sort of come in with a bucket of money and suggest that we do some work in an area.
The people here would kind of decide how the money should be spent.
If there was a lot of money in the bucket at the end of the year, no one was concerned about it, that there might be any less the next year because we hadn't spent it all.
I mean, they spent what they had to spend to get the job done.
And if the bucket ran dry for some reason, why, they'd simply go back to the Army and say, hey, you know, can you fill up the bucket partway again?
And usually the bucket would get filled up.
And nobody was concerned in those days about which charge number to charge this hour's work to, or it was just
There were broad tasks being assigned to JPL, and the people here decided how best to carry them out, and the money always seemed available.
So in that sense, the working relationship was great.
It was ideal.
But, of course, the work being done was work on missiles like the Sergeant, for example.
So the whole idea of converting our expertise over to JPL
Learning more about the solar system was just, I don't know, I think everybody reacted with great enthusiasm, with a few exceptions.
